<Summary source="https://www.greaterwrong.com/posts/gogZyeistdaDFuhbG/claude-plays-pokemon-opus-4-5-follow-up">
# Summary of "Claude Plays Pokemon: Opus 4.5 Follow-up"

**Source:** Greaterwrong  
**Date:** January 29, 2026  
**Author:** Josh Snider

## Key Facts and Progress Updates

**Current Status (as of article date):**
- Claude is stuck in Victory Road at 230,000 steps, attempting to complete boulder puzzles
- Has not yet beaten the game (has not defeated Champion Blue)

**Progress Since Previous Article:**
- The previous article (published ~2 months earlier, around November 2025) was written at 48,000 steps when Claude was stuck in Silph Co
- Since then, Claude has:
  - Beaten Silph Co
  - Completed Safari Zone
  - Got stuck in Pokemon Mansion, then completed it
  - Obtained all eight badges
  - Reached Victory Road

**Technical Issues:**
- Claude initially missed the Gold Teeth in Safari Zone (needed to get HM for STRENGTH, which is required to push boulders in Victory Road)
- Claude later realized the mistake and successfully backtracked to retrieve them after beating Pokemon Mansion

## Capabilities Assessment

**Improvements in Claude Opus 4.5:**
- Better vision (though still "pretty bad" according to author)
- Improved spatial awareness
- Improved use of context window
- Improved ability to notice and escape loops
- Long-term planning remains poor

**Key Observation:**
The author notes that "persistence does wonders" - Claude overcomes skill issues by not giving up, even after spending weeks on seemingly insurmountable obstacles. Viewers routinely declared the run doomed before Claude eventually found solutions.

## Author's Opinions and Predictions

- Author expects Claude would beat the game "given unlimited time"
- Author believes Claude Plays Pokemon "represents the best test of underlying LLM progress" compared to similar projects that provide more assistance
- Author expresses concern that Anthropic hasn't prioritized fixing vision issues, referencing Dario's comment at Davos about potentially buying an image model if needed
- Author mentions upcoming reset expected when next Claude model is released
- Author has "short timelines" regarding AI development

**Note:** The article mentions a Manifold market and "rumor mill" suggesting a new Claude model release is imminent, which would trigger a reset of the experiment.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://arstechnica.com/civis/threads/why-anthropic%E2%80%99s-claude-still-hasn%E2%80%99t-beaten-pok%C3%A9mon.1506342/">
# Summary of "Why Anthropic's Claude still hasn't beaten Pokémon"

**Source:** Ars OpenForum  
**Date:** March 21, 2025

## Key Facts and Observations:

1. **Current Status:** In the weeks since Claude Plays Pokémon was first made public, thousands of Twitch viewers have watched Claude struggle to make consistent progress in the game.

2. **Model Used:** The article references Sonnet's "reasoning" model struggling with a game designed for children.

3. **Technical Assistance:** Claude monitors emulated Game Boy RAM addresses for game state information, including inventory, Pokémon status, and current rival. This information is visible in the "Tools" section of the Visual Guide mentioned in the piece. The system cannot manipulate RNG or predict incoming attacks.

4. **Learning Approach:** Claude uses a combination of:
   - Feedback from the game itself
   - Knowledge of Pokémon from its training data
   - Information gleaned from in-game text prompts

## Opinions and Commentary:

**Named Source:**
- Nobel Prize Winner Geoffrey Hinton is quoted regarding AI understanding: "these millions of features and billions of interactions between features that they learn are understanding"

**Unnamed/Forum Commenters (less reliable):**
- Multiple commenters debate whether RAM monitoring constitutes "cheating" - consensus among some is that it's not cheating for game purposes but represents "a fairly massive cheat for 'throw generalized reasoning model at problem' purposes" as it reduces UI interactions and short-term memory requirements
- One commenter notes Claude "came into this with a pretty decent understanding of the mechanics of the games, the individual moves and pokemon, and the general route needed to beat the game"
- Anthropic's perspective (paraphrased by commenter): This is "an interesting thing to use as a benchmark" that highlights weaknesses of current and past models while showing progress in certain areas
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://futurism.com/advanced-ai-stuck-pokemon">
# Summary of Article: "One of the World's Most Advanced AI Agents Is Completely Stuck Trying to Beat a Pokémon Game for Children"

**Source:** Futurism  
**Date:** March 21, 2025  
**Author:** Frank Landymore

## Key Facts and Statistics:

- Anthropic is livestreaming Claude 3.7 Sonnet attempting to complete Pokémon Red in an experiment called "Claude Plays Pokémon"
- As of the article's publication, Claude has obtained three Gym badges and reached Cerulean City
- Claude spent nearly 80 hours stuck in Mt. Moon before finding the exit ladder
- The AI's predecessor, Claude 3.0 Sonnet, couldn't even make it out of Pallet Town (the game's starting area)

## Current Status and Challenges:

- Claude is currently stuck trying to access Route 5
- The AI is using process of elimination to find the Route 5 entrance but keeps looking for a "gatehouse" instead of recognizing it needs to use the HM "Cut" ability on destructible trees
- The AI stops to "think" after every single move, sometimes for extended intervals
- Claude has been observed running around in circles, unsure of its next move

## Expert Opinion (Named Source):

**David Hershey, Anthropic engineer behind the experiment** (interviewed by Ars Technica):
- "Claude's still not particularly good at understanding what's on the screen at all. You will see it attempt to walk into walls all the time."
- Suggests Claude might perform better in a more visually realistic game: "It's pretty easy for me to understand that [an in-game] building is a building and that I can't walk through a building. And that's [something] that's pretty challenging for Claude to understand."
- Notes Claude shows surprising cleverness in some areas, such as responding appropriately to misleading in-game clues (example: finding Professor Oak at the start of the game)
- "It's sophisticated enough to sort of go through the motions of the way [humans are] actually supposed to learn it, too."

## Technical Details:

- Claude excels at interpreting text-based portions of the game, including Pokémon battles
- The AI has access to the game's RAM to obtain information like in-game coordinates
- Major challenge: visually processing the low-resolution pixel environment

## General Assessment (Author's opinion):

The article suggests Claude's struggles demonstrate that AI agent technology "still has a long way to go to be 'agentic,' let alone fulfill its promise of one day exceeding human capabilities."
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://mashable.com/article/anthropic-ai-agent-claude-pokemon-red-livestream">
# Summary of Mashable Article (March 24, 2025)

## Key Facts and Timeline:

- **Project Launch**: Anthropic launched the "Claude Plays Pokémon" Twitch livestream in February 2025 (approximately one month before the article's publication date)

- **Historical Performance**: 
  - Claude 3.5 (June 2024): Failed at basic tasks, would try to run away from almost every battle
  - Claude 3.7 Sonnet (February 2025): Showed significant improvement

- **Progress Milestones**:
  - Within hours: Claude 3.7 defeated Brock
  - Days later: Claude 3.7 defeated Misty
  - Mt. Moon: Took 78 hours to complete (compared to a few hours for a typical child, according to Reddit gamers' estimates)

## Technical Capabilities (According to Anthropic):

Claude 3.7 Sonnet can:
- Plan ahead
- Remember objectives
- Learn from mistakes
- Build a knowledge base
- See the screen
- Simulate button presses

## Performance Analysis:

**Strengths**: Better at text-based aspects of the game (e.g., Pokémon battles)

**Weaknesses**: Struggles with visual/spatial navigation aspects (moving around the map from town to town)

Observable behaviors include going in circles, stumbling around the same paths, and knocking into walls

## Source Attribution:

- Direct quotes attributed to Anthropic
- Gaming estimates from Reddit users (less reliable source)
- Additional information from Anthropic engineers via Ars Technica interview

## Current Status (as of March 24, 2025):

The livestream is still ongoing, but progress has stalled. Claude has not completed the game and still has "151 Pokémon to catch."
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.tomshardware.com/tech-industry/artificial-intelligence/google-openai-and-anthropic-are-competing-to-see-whose-ai-can-play-pokemon-the-best-twitch-streams-of-beloved-rpg-game-test-the-models-true-might">
# Summary of Article: "Google, OpenAI, and Anthropic are competing to see whose AI can play Pokémon the best"

**Source:** Tom's Hardware  
**Date:** January 24, 2026  
**Author:** Hassam Nasir

## Key Facts and Statements:

### Current Status of AI Pokémon Players:
- **Claude (Anthropic):** No version of Claude has successfully beaten Pokémon Blue yet. The latest Opus 4.5 model is currently attempting the challenge on stream.
- **Gemini (Google) and GPT (OpenAI):** Both have already beaten Pokémon Blue and have moved on to the sequels.

### Background on the Project:
- The "Claude Plays Pokémon" stream was started last year by David Hershey, Anthropic's applied AI lead.
- Claude's gaming efforts inspired freelance developers to create similar "Gemini Plays Pokémon" and "GPT Plays Pokémon" streams.
- These projects have received official recognition from Google and OpenAI, with their labs occasionally tweaking the models.

### Expert Opinion (Named Source):
**David Hershey (Anthropic AI lead)** stated:
- "The thing that has made Pokémon fun and that has captured the [machine learning] community's interest is that it's a lot less constrained than Pong or some of the other games that people have historically done this on. It's a pretty hard problem for a computer program to be able to do."
- Using Pokémon to test AI models "provides [us] with, like, this great way to just see how a model is doing and to evaluate it in a quantitative way."

### Why Pokémon is Used as a Benchmark:
- The game requires judgment, logical reasoning, risk assessment, and long-term thinking.
- Players must make strategic choices about leveling up, training existing Pokémon, or capturing new ones.
- Completing the game requires winning the Pokémon League through several successive steps, testing strategic planning and resource management.
- Performance is easily quantifiable rather than subjective.

### Application of Findings:
- David Hershey shares findings from Pokémon streams with customers to improve the "harness" (software framework) around AI for specific tasks.
- The learnings are applied to real-world clients looking to improve compute efficiency.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.iphoneincanada.ca/2026/01/24/why-your-childhood-pokemon-games-are-the-newest-test-for-advanced-ai/">
# Summary of Article: "Why Your Childhood Pokémon Games Are the Newest Test for Advanced AI"

**Source:** iPhone in Canada  
**Date:** January 24, 2026  
**Author:** Austin Blake

## Key Facts and Statistics:

1. **AI Labs Using Pokémon Games as Benchmarks:** Major AI labs are using original Pokémon games (Pokémon Blue and Red from the 1990s) to test AI models' reasoning, planning, and long-term goal capabilities.

2. **Multiple AI Streams Exist:** 
   - "Claude Plays Pokémon" launched in February [2025, based on context]
   - Similar experiments followed: "GPT Plays Pokémon" (OpenAI) and "Gemini Plays Pokémon" (Google)

3. **Completion Status (as of article date):**
   - **No AI model has fully beaten the game without help** according to David Hershey
   - **Both GPT and Gemini have completed the original Pokémon game** with different setups
   - These models are now being tested on Pokémon sequels

4. **Public Engagement:** The Pokémon AI streams have drawn "hundreds of thousands of comments" from viewers

## Named Source Opinions:

**David Hershey (Applied AI Lead at Anthropic):**
- "It provides us with like this great way to just see how a model is doing and to evaluate it in a quantitative way"
- "The thing that has made Pokémon fun and that has captured the [machine learning] community's interest is that it's a lot less constrained than Pong or some of the other games that people have historically done this on. It's a pretty hard problem for a computer program to be able to do."
- Notes that progress comes from building better supporting software (harness), including memory systems

**Jonathan Verron (Developer behind Pokémon AI streams):**
- "This is a perfect game for AI right now. I've tried to think about other games, but I haven't found as good an example as Pokémon."

## Additional Context:

- OpenAI reportedly had a live Pokémon stream playing on a TV inside its office
- Google CEO Sundar Pichai publicly praised Gemini's progress in the game
- Anthropic has brought "Claude Plays Pokémon" booths to industry conferences and hosts an internal Slack channel for employees to track Claude's progress
</Summary>

**From 1996 to 2026: How the World and Pokémon Have Changed in 30 Years**
From 1996 to 2026, Pokémon has evolved dramatically alongside technological and societal changes. Initially released on handheld consoles with monochrome screens, the franchise transitioned to high-definition open worlds, reflecting shifts from analog to digital culture. In 1996, internet access in Spain was minimal (320,000 users), and Pokémon games were not globally available—Spain received Blue and Blastoise instead of Green and Venusaur. The anime, featuring Ash and Pikachu, was a central entertainment hub, with viewers relying on friends or reruns to catch missed episodes. The original Pokémon Red and Green introduced revolutionary mechanics like trading between versions and a 151-creature Pokédex, sparking a global phenomenon. By 1999, internet culture began shaping society, with IRC and ICQ dominating communication and 56k modems defining connectivity. The rise of Game Boy Color and the success of Gold and Silver marked a leap in gameplay with features like real-time progression and a second region. In 2002, post-9/11 global anxiety influenced media, with fantasy franchises like The Lord of the Rings and Harry Potter offering escapism. The launch of Nintendo DS and Wii in 2006 ushered in a new era of accessible, intuitive gaming, enabling Pokémon Diamond and Pearl to introduce Wi-Fi connectivity and the Global Trade Station, transforming Pokémon into a global, real-time social experience. By 2010, smartphones and social media reshaped attention spans, leading to the rise of mobile gaming and the decline of handhelds. Pokémon Black and White embraced DS’s capabilities with a new region, a darker narrative, and a fully original Pokédex. In 2013, Pokémon X and Y made a landmark leap to 3D, introduced Mega Evolution, and launched simultaneously worldwide—reflecting a hyperconnected era. The 2016 release of Pokémon GO redefined the franchise, turning it into a global augmented reality phenomenon. Pokémon Sun and Moon introduced Alola, a Hawaiian-inspired region with unique mechanics like Island Challenges and regional forms. The 2019 release of Sword and Shield brought the first true open world with the Wild Area and Dynamax battles, though it sparked backlash over the loss of the National Pokédex and the controversial 'Dexit' decision. In 2022, Scarlet and Violet broke from tradition with Paldea, the first open-world Pokémon region, offering unprecedented freedom of exploration. However, the games were plagued by technical issues, including bugs, glitches, and performance problems, sparking criticism despite record sales. Over 30 years, Pokémon has mirrored societal evolution—from analog to digital, from linear gameplay to open worlds—while maintaining its core appeal: a reliable refuge in a changing world. The franchise continues to balance innovation with nostalgia, aiming to remain relevant across generations.

**Pokémon GCC: What Are the Card Sets Coming in 2026?**
The Pokémon Trading Card Game (GCC) is set for another significant year in 2026, following a rich 2025. The Megaevolution Series, officially launched in October 2025, continues with two major expansions: 'Ascesa Eroica,' released on January 30, 2026, and 'Equilibrio Perfetto,' scheduled for March 27, 2026. 'Ascesa Eroica' features 295 cards—217 regular and 78 secret—inspired by the Nintendo Switch and Switch 2 game 'Leggende Pokémon: Z-A.' It introduces the 'J' regulation symbol for the first time and includes Megaevolution Pokémon-ex and new trainer cards. The Pokémon Day 2026 Collection, released on January 30, 2026, includes a special holographic Pikachu promo card, a 30th-anniversary logo coin, and three booster packs from different GCC expansions. Each booster pack contains 10 cards, one basic Energy card, and a code card for the GCC Pokémon Live platform. 'Equilibrio Perfetto' will be the third main expansion of the Megaevolution Series and the first set set in Luminopoli, the city from 'Leggende Pokémon: Z-A.' It will feature over 120 cards, including 4 Megaevolution Pokémon-ex (Mega Zygarde-ex, Mega Starmie-ex, Mega Clefable-ex, and Mega Skarmory-ex), 9 Pokémon-ex, 11 rare illustrated Pokémon cards, 18 Pokémon and Trainer cards in ultra-rare versions, and 6 special illustrated rare support cards. The release calendar for 'Ascesa Eroica' includes additional drops on February 20 and April 24, 2026.

**I Love Pokemon, But I'm Excited to See a New Side of Game Freak with Beast of Reincarnation**
The article discusses the upcoming non-Pokemon AAA RPG 'Beast of Reincarnation' by Game Freak, the studio behind the Pokémon franchise. Though Game Freak is closely associated with Pokémon, it is not owned by Nintendo, allowing it to develop titles with other publishers. The game, set to release on PC, PS5, and Xbox Series X|S later in 2026, marks Game Freak's first major console title outside the Pokémon series. It features a realistic 3D world, a darker narrative, and a protagonist who forms a deep bond with a canine companion, departing from Pokémon’s signature cartoon aesthetic. The article notes that many Pokémon fans have grown dissatisfied with the franchise’s recent graphical style, particularly the flat, unrealistic visuals in games like Pokémon Scarlet & Violet, and the lack of innovation in gameplay. While the author expresses love for Pokémon and anticipation for the next main series entry, they admit to feeling a sense of fatigue with the repetitive 'catch 'em all' loop. The article highlights that 'Beast of Reincarnation' offers a chance to see Game Freak’s creative potential beyond Pokémon, combining the studio’s strengths in storytelling and character-driven RPGs with a more mature, visually ambitious design. The game’s reveal has generated excitement for its narrative depth, realistic visuals, and departure from the Pokémon formula.

**Chatbots go to space: NASA used Claude AI to navigate its Perseverance rover across Mars - The Times of India**
NASA's Perseverance rover traversed 400 meters across Mars on December 8 and 10, 2025, following a route autonomously planned by Anthropic's Claude AI—the first time a chatbot has directed machinery on another planet. Engineers at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) provided Claude with years of rover data and orbital imagery from the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter. The AI generated commands in Rover Markup Language (a specialized XML-based code), breaking the route into 10-meter segments and self-critiquing waypoints to refine the path. JPL tested the route using Perseverance’s digital twin, simulating over 500,000 variables; one issue was identified—sand ripples near a narrow corridor not visible in the AI’s initial analysis—prompting a manual adjustment. The remaining path held up under testing. The innovation cuts planning time in half, according to JPL estimates, enabling more drives, more rock sample collection, and enhanced scientific exploration in Jezero Crater—a site once holding water and potentially habitable for microbial life. This is critical given the 20-minute Earth-Mars signal delay, which makes real-time remote driving impossible, and NASA’s workforce reduction of approximately 4,000 employees due to budget cuts. The development marks a significant leap for Anthropic, whose AI previously could not beat Pokémon Red. The timing is strategic as NASA prepares for the Artemis moon missions.

**When & What to Expect From Pokemon Day 2026**
Pokemon Day 2026, celebrated on February 27, marks the 30th anniversary of the original Pokemon Red and Green release in Japan, and is expected to be the most significant celebration yet. The event will center around a global Pokemon Presents livestream, likely airing in the early afternoon Central European Time (very early morning EST, earlier on the West Coast), lasting 15–30 minutes and featuring major announcements. Key highlights include the official reveal of Pokemon Generation 10, expected to be announced during the final segment of the presentation with a likely 2026 holiday release to commemorate the anniversary. The event will also feature a confirmed release date or blockbuster trailer for Pokemon Champions, a cross-platform strategic battle game slated for Nintendo Switch, iOS, and Android, supporting multiplayer, cross-play, and integration with Pokemon Home. Pokemon Pokopia, a sandbox-style game akin to Stardew Valley, is set for an early March 2026 launch on Nintendo Switch 2 and may receive a gameplay trailer during the broadcast. Mobile and franchise-wide updates are anticipated, including new Pokemon TCG Pocket expansions, in-game bonuses for Scarlet and Violet, and special events across Pokemon Go and Unite. LEGO Pokemon sets, including the first-ever LEGO Pokemon collection featuring Venusaur, Charizard, and Blastoise, will launch on February 27, 2026, and may be spotlighted during the event. The 30th anniversary celebration could also include exclusive merchandise, nostalgia-driven content such as the classic Pikachu design, and potential remasters of classic Pokemon games. According to Game Rant, the article was published on January 31, 2026, 15:00.

**This is How You Beat The Anti-Fun Police in Pokemon Legends: Z-A Now That Season 6 is Live**
Pokemon Legends: Z-A's Season 6, released on January 29, introduced significant changes including the release of Swampertite for Mega Swampert and a meta dominated by powerful restricted Legendary Pokemon such as Xerneas, Kyogre, Rayquaza, and Groudon, which the author argues creates a repetitive, forced, and unfun environment. Despite this, the author demonstrates that it is possible to succeed and enjoy ranked battles without using any Legendary or Mythical Pokemon. The recommended team includes Overqwil (Dark/Poison) with Shuca Berry and a set to counter Xerneas, Rotom (Mow Form, Electric/Grass) with Magnet and a size XS form for stealth, and Swampert with Assault Vest to resist special attacks. This team has achieved consistent results—landing last place only once in over 40 matches—primarily due to Rotom's high effectiveness as a sniper. Alternative options like Gholdengo with Nasty Plot and Shadow Ball are also suggested. The author acknowledges the appeal of using Legendaries but emphasizes that a non-Legendary team can still be both competitive and enjoyable, promoting meta diversity. The game was released on October 16, 2025, and received a critic score of 79/100 on OpenCritic.

**Aniimo Could Be a Solid Pokemon and Palworld Rival, If Your PC Can Handle It (Preview)**
Aniimo, a free-to-play creature collector developed by Pawprint Studio and Kingslory, is generating anticipation among fans of Pokémon and cozy games. The game's second Closed Beta, launched on January 23, 2026, offers a visually stunning, open-world experience with anime-inspired aesthetics, exploration, and puzzle-solving elements. Unlike Palworld, Aniimo emphasizes open-ended exploration over survival and base-building, with a story-driven but largely player-directed progression. Core gameplay includes catching 'aniimo' using a mechanic similar to Palworld and Pokémon Legends: Arceus, enhanced by a unique 'Twining' feature that allows players to temporarily become their collected aniimo to solve environmental puzzles, access restricted areas, and traverse the world. The game integrates MMO-style social features with non-intrusive in-game chat. While the beta version shows promise with intuitive tutorials and engaging world design, it suffers from an overabundance of menus, currencies, and unclear reward systems typical of free-to-play titles. Notably, the game demands high PC specifications—straining older systems and even some modern laptops—raising concerns about accessibility. However, the planned multiplatform release (PC, mobile, Xbox Series X|S) may mitigate these performance issues. Despite rough edges, Aniimo shows strong potential as a rival to Pokémon and Palworld, particularly for players seeking a visually rich, open-world creature-collecting experience with innovative mechanics. The full release is expected in 2026.

**NASA used Claude to plot a route for its Perseverance rover on Mars**
NASA successfully used Anthropic's Claude large language model to plot a 400-meter route through a rocky area of Mars' Jezero crater for its Perseverance rover between December 8 and 10, 2025, marking the first time an AI model has been used to pilot the rover. The task required Claude to process years of contextual data from the rover, generate waypoints in ten-meter segments, and iteratively refine the route. NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) engineers verified the AI-generated path using their standard simulation system, making only minor adjustments—such as one based on ground-level images not available to Claude during planning. NASA estimates that using Claude reduces route-planning time by half, increases consistency, and allows operators to conduct more drives, collect more scientific data, and perform more analysis. This advancement is particularly significant given NASA's workforce reduction of about 4,000 employees (20% of its workforce) due to Trump administration cuts and a proposed 50% cut to its science budget in 2025, which Congress rejected. The success highlights a dramatic leap for Anthropic, whose Claude model evolved from failing to beat Pokémon Red in 2024 to enabling interplanetary navigation in under a year. NASA expressed excitement about future collaborations, noting that autonomous AI systems could enable probes to explore more distant parts of the solar system.

**Claude Plays Pokemon: Opus 4.5 Follow-up -- LessWrong**
ClaudePlaysPokemon is a project testing whether the LLM Claude can beat Pokémon Red, with progress tracked across successive Claude model releases. The article updates insights from a prior piece written two months after the release of Claude Opus 4.5, noting that the model has advanced significantly since the original analysis. After the initial article, Claude overcame key obstacles: he beat Silph Co, completed the Safari Zone, solved Pokemon Mansion, collected all eight badges, and reached Victory Road, where he remains stuck on boulder puzzles. Key observations from the original analysis still hold: Claude has better vision (though still poor), improved spatial awareness, better use of context window, enhanced ability to detect and escape loops, and persistence despite frequent stalling. However, long-term planning remains weak—evidenced by his failure to collect Gold Teeth in the Safari Zone, which are required to obtain the HM for STRENGTH. Fortunately, he later realized the oversight and backtracked successfully. The article emphasizes that persistence, not flawless reasoning, enables progress. The author notes that while Claude may eventually beat the game with unlimited time, the upcoming release of a new Claude model is expected to reset the run soon, potentially accelerating progress. The project is seen as a rigorous benchmark of LLM capabilities, more authentic than other tests that rely on external assistance.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 29, 2026 04:14 PM
Source:[Maya Farber Brodsky](https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/gogZyeistdaDFuhbG/claude-plays-pokemon-opus-4-5-follow-up)

**Why Your Childhood Pokémon Games Are the Newest Test for Advanced AI | iPhone in Canada**
Classic 1990s Pokémon games, including Pokémon Red and Blue, are being used as a benchmark for evaluating advanced artificial intelligence models, according to a report from the Wall Street Journal. Major AI labs such as Anthropic, OpenAI, and Google are leveraging these games to test AI capabilities in reasoning, long-term planning, memory retention, and adaptive decision-making—skills not easily measured through traditional question-and-answer formats. David Hershey, applied AI lead at Anthropic, emphasized that Pokémon provides a 'quantitative way' to assess AI performance, noting its open-ended nature and unpredictability make it more challenging than games like chess or Go. The 'Claude Plays Pokémon' livestream on Twitch, launched in February 2025, inspired similar projects like 'GPT Plays Pokémon' and 'Gemini Plays Pokémon.' These streams have drawn hundreds of thousands of online viewers, with internal AI progress tracked via Slack channels and physical booths at industry conferences. While no AI model has yet fully beaten the original game without assistance, newer models are improving, aided by advanced 'harness' software including memory systems. OpenAI and Google have reported completing the original game using different setups, and development teams are now testing models on sequels. Jonathan Verron, one of the developers behind the streams, stated that Pokémon is 'the perfect game for AI right now' due to its complexity and lack of rigid constraints. The trend reflects a broader shift in AI evaluation toward real-world-like, dynamic environments.

**How Pikachu Helps Your Favorite AI Get Better**
Pokémon games, originally released by Nintendo in the late 1990s, have evolved into a key tool for training and evaluating advanced artificial intelligence models in the 21st century. Companies such as OpenAI, Google, and Anthropic use Pokémon titles as cognitive testing environments, assessing AI capabilities in planning, decision-making, and handling unpredictable scenarios. The games' combination of narrative, exploration, strategy, and resource management makes them uniquely effective for testing AI. Live streams on Twitch—such as 'Claude Plays Pokémon', 'GPT Plays Pokémon', and 'Gemini Plays Pokémon'—have become both entertainment and professional evaluation tools, with results featured in corporate presentations and internal reports. This trend follows earlier milestones like AlphaGo’s victory over a human Go champion in 2016 and Minecraft’s use as a testing environment. The Kaggle Game Arena, launched by Google, hosted a Pokémon-based competition in August 2025, won by OpenAI’s o3 model. Challenges include managing Pokémon training, resource allocation, and solving spatial puzzles—complex tasks for AI systems. The cultural impact is significant: OpenAI employees watched AI-generated Pokémon streams in the office, Google CEO Sundar Pichai celebrated Gemini’s win at Google I/O, and Anthropic uses Pokémon in trade show booths and internal monitoring channels. Recent models like Claude Opus 4.5 have attempted live full-game completion, while GPT and Gemini have completed the original game, though with the aid of custom tools. Ultimately, Pokémon, through characters like Pikachu and Charizard, plays an unexpected role in helping machines think more effectively, transforming technical benchmarks into public spectacles.

**How playing Pokémon became the ultimate test of AI's intelligence**
Nintendo's original Pokémon games, particularly Pokémon Blue on the Game Boy, have become a popular and effective benchmark for evaluating artificial intelligence models in Silicon Valley. David Hershey, applied AI lead at Anthropic, developed the 'Claude Plays Pokémon' Twitch stream in February 2024, which inspired similar streams featuring OpenAI’s GPT and Google’s Gemini. These live streams, which have drawn hundreds of thousands of comments, allow real-time tracking of AI models’ reasoning, decision-making, and long-term goal progression—offering a more holistic evaluation than traditional question-and-answer benchmarks. Unlike simpler games such as Pong or chess, Pokémon presents complex challenges including maze navigation, strategic team-building, and puzzle-solving, making it a 'hard problem' for AI. Anthropic uses the 'harness' framework—such as a memory system—to improve Claude’s performance, and these insights are now applied to real-world customer deployments. While no AI has yet beaten the original game, newer versions like Claude Opus 4.5 are actively attempting it live on Twitch. OpenAI and Google have also achieved victories in the original game, likely due to advanced harnesses. Both companies are now advancing to sequel games. Developers like Joel Zhang and Jonathan Verron, who built the GPT and Gemini streams, describe Pokémon as 'the perfect game for AI right now,' citing its balance of complexity, open-endedness, and nostalgic appeal. The phenomenon has also inspired fan art, internal Slack channels at Anthropic, and even a booth at industry conferences. As Hershey noted, 'We're all a whole bunch of nerds,' highlighting both the community-driven and technically rigorous nature of the trend.

**Why the World's Best AI Systems Are Still So Bad at Pokémon**
Large language models (LLMs) continue to struggle with playing Pokémon Red, a 1996 Game Boy game, despite advancements in AI capabilities. The challenge began in February 2024 when Anthropic launched a livestream of Claude Sonnet 3.7 playing the game, marking the first time a Claude model could meaningfully engage with it—previous versions 'wandered aimlessly or got stuck in loops' and failed to progress beyond the opening stages. Although Sonnet 3.7 attracted around 2,000 viewers during its stream, it could not complete the game, often getting stuck for dozens of hours. The latest model, Claude Opus 4.5, performs better but still frequently fails, such as spending four days circling a gym without entering because it failed to recognize it needed to cut down a tree. In contrast, Google's Gemini models completed a similar game in May 2024, prompting CEO Sundar Pichai to humorously claim Google was 'one step closer to creating Artificial Pokémon Intelligence.' The difficulty AI systems face with Pokémon reflects broader limitations in real-world reasoning, consistency, and situational awareness, offering more meaningful insight into their capabilities than traditional benchmark metrics.

**New Board Game 'SLIDE' to Launch in Japan on December 19, 2025**
Studio Mundii Co., Ltd. (based in Minato, Tokyo, CEO: Hiroyuki Nakajima) will release the new board game 'SLIDE' (Japanese edition) on Friday, December 19, 2025. The game is priced at a suggested retail price of 2,970 yen (tax included). It is a simple yet strategic game where players arrange 16 cards (each numbered 1 to 10, with 10 copies per number) in a 4×4 grid face-down. After a rock-paper-scissors match to determine the starting player, each round involves players simultaneously selecting one card, which is then placed into their grid by sliding it from the outside. The game ends after 16 rounds, when all cards are face-up. Points are calculated by eliminating connected pairs of identical numbers; any remaining unpaired numbers result in negative points. The player with the fewest negative points wins. The game supports 2–6 players, lasts about 15 minutes, and is suitable for ages 7 and up. The game was designed by Claude Clément and features artwork by Joey. It will be available through Amazon and nationwide electronics retailers, toy stores, and board game shops. Studio Mundii also announced upcoming releases for 2026, including 'Arcade Challenger' (spring), 'Exghost: The Ghost Eraser' (summer), 'Paw! Cat Ludo' (summer), 'Let's Go Thank You Tiger Boy!' (autumn), 'Pit In!' (winter), and an unnamed title for spring 2027.
